titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Philosophy and Social Science Manuscripts Collection
Philosophy and Social Science Manuscripts Collection

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 09:58

did.unittitle: Philosophy and social science manuscripts collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: An artificial collection of notes, lectures, student papers, scrapbooks, and writings relating to the study and teaching of the academic disciplines in the social sciences including economics, education, psychology, political science, philosophy, and sociology, 1866-1967. The papers of Charles Andrews Armstrong Bennett, Albert Bushnell Hart, Wilmon Henry Sheldon, Wilbur Marshall Urban, and Alfred North Whitehead are included.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Philosophy and Social Science Manuscripts Collection (MS 644). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by individuals whose papers are included in the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The primary purpose of this register is to provide the researcher with a convenient guide to collections of manuscripts in the Sterling Memorial Library which, owing to their content or provenance, fall into the social science category, but which are too small to warrant separate descriptions.

For the present purpose "Social Science" has been broadly defined to include all those disciplines which were historically derived from Moral Philosophy in the mid-nineteenth century, together with certain related subject areas. Thus, the Philosophy and Social Science Manuscripts Group includes manuscripts relating to psychology, philosophy, education, law, economics, and political science. This group does not include manuscripts related to the humanities and the fine arts nor to those disciplines which derived from Natural Philosophy; those have been described separately in the guides to the Humanities and Fine Arts Manuscripts Group and the Natural Science Manuscripts Group respectively.

It should be re-emphasized that there are a number of separate large collections relating to philosophy and the social sciences that have been separately described and are not included in this register.
Consult the Chief Research Archivist, Manuscripts and Archives, for further information about all of these collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Andrew Armstrong Bennett was born in Ireland in 1885. He received his B.A. from Queen's College, Oxford, in 1908, and his Ph.D. from Yale in 1913. He taught philosophy at Yale until 1929. In 1923 he published A Philosophical Study of Mysticism and in 1931 a series of his lectures was published under the title The Dilemma of Religious Knowledge . Bennett died in 1930.

Wilbur Marshall Urban was born in 1873, received an A.B. from Princeton in 1895 and a Ph.D. from Leipzig in 1897. He taught at various colleges, including Princeton and Dartmouth, and became professor of philosophy at Yale in 1931, where he was also chairman of the department. In 1941 he became professor emeritus. Urban died in 1952.

Albert Bushnell Hart was born in 1854, received his A.B. from Harvard in 1880 and his Ph.D. from Freidburg, Baden, in 1883. He taught history and government at Harvard from 1883, becoming professor in 1897 and professor emeritus in 1926. He has written and edited numerous volumes on American history and government. Hart died in 1943.

Wilmon H. Sheldon was born in Newton, Massachusetts on April 4, 1875. He graduated from Harvard in 1895 from which he also received his M.A. in 1896 and his Ph.D. in philosophy in 1899. Sheldon taught philosophy at the University of Wisconsin, 1899-1900; Harvard, 1901-1903; Columbia, 1903-1905; Princeton, 1905-1909; and Dartmouth, 1909-1920, before coming to Yale, where he was professor of philosophy from 1920 and emeritus professor from 1943. Among his most important works are: Strife and Systems and Productive Duality (1918), America's Progressive Philosophy (1942), and Process and Polarity (1944).

Alfred North Whitehead was born at Ramsgate, England on February 15, 1861. He received his B.A. from Trinity College, Cambridge in 1884 and an M.A. in 1887. Whitehead lectured on mathematics at Trinity College from, 1885 to 1911 and at the University of London from 1911 to 1924. In 1924 he joined the faculty of Harvard University as professor of philosophy, becoming emeritus professor in 1936.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though some of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of papers consists almost entirely of notes on various philosophical topics, some of which were apparently taken while Bennett was a graduate student; others appear to be notes for his own lectures. There are also a few lectures on the philosophy of religion, two items of correspondence, copies of examinations, a few students' papers and some printed material relating to the first world war.

It should be noted that originally this material was mixed with, and so mistakenly identified as, that of Wilbur Urban, Bennett's successor at Yale (q.v.). That material which is dated or signed is almost certainly Bennett's, but it is possible that some of Urban's papers remain with Bennett's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These papers contain a large number of papers written for Urban by his students, mainly on ethics and on Kant. There are also two items of correspondence and a book manuscript, God and the Historians and Other Studies in the Philosophy of History , written by Urban in 1949.

It should be noted that this material was originally mixed with the materials of Charles A. A. Bennett, Urban's predecessor at Yale (q.v.). Although the two groups of material have been separated as far as possible, some of Urban's material may still be in Bennett's papers.

did.unittitle: from: Kujawa, Jan (enclosed writings) to: Otrander, Harry J.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These papers consist of a series of scrapbooks concerning various aspects of elections and voting behavior with the exception of one scrapbook pertaining to political corruption and some notes about the aldermen of New Haven. The material from the scrapbooks includes clippings from newspapers, magazines and books; pamphlets; and notes, papers, and reports by students. Among the student papers there are a few letters from Hart to students about their papers. Also in the papers are letters from Edward Gaylord Bourne (q.v.) concerning his book, Spain in America , published in the American Nation series which Hart edited.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of papers consists primarily of manuscript drafts of his books, Rational Religion: The Philosophy of Christian Love , published in 1962, and Sex and Salvation , published in 1955. In addition, there are a few notes on religion and metaphysics and an article on Sheldon's philosophy by Peter H. Hare.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a bound typescript of student notes taken from lectures of A.N. Whitehead at Harvard University from 1926 to 1937. The notes were compiled by: George P. Conger, William K. Frankena, A.H. Johnson John L. Mothershead, Jr., W. V. Quine, and Edward Schouten Robinson, and the entire collection compiled and typed by members of the Graduate Philosophy Club of Yale University in 1966. A copy of the table of contents follows.

did.unittitle: Notes from "Lectures of A. N. W. at Harvard" Compiled by students
